frontmatter.title: Building the SSA Baby Names Data Pipeline (1880–2024)
frontmatter.summary: How I stitched 145 SSA text files into a clean 2.1M-row dataset and prepared it for Tableau storytelling.

content:
# Building the SSA Baby Names Data Pipeline (1880–2024)

This post documents the exact ingestion and cleanup steps behind the Baby Names visual story. The goal was a single, tidy table that could drive both Python analysis and Tableau dashboards without manual fixes.

## Source Files

- 145 SSA text files (1880–2024)
- Fields: name, sex, count, year
- Minimum count per name-year enforced by SSA source

## Core Cleaning Decisions

- Concatenated all yearly files into one dataset
- Standardized column names and data types
- Validated categorical values for `sex` (F, M)
- Ensured no missing values across core fields

## Output Snapshot

- **Rows:** 2,149,477
- **Years:** 1880–2024
- **Nulls:** 0 missing across core fields

## Why This Matters for Viz

Once the data was flat and consistent, it became trivial to generate:

- Year-over-year birth counts
- Generation-based top-10 lists
- Gender split comparisons

If you want to reproduce the pipeline, the notebook in the repo walks through every step and includes the final CSV export.

frontmatter.title: Unisex Baby Names: Balancing Female vs Male Usage
frontmatter.summary: A focused look at unisex name balance using SSA counts and a gender-split chart.

content:
# Unisex Baby Names: Balancing Female vs Male Usage

The Baby Names project surfaces a set of names that show meaningful balance between female and male usage. Rather than highlight one-year spikes, I used the full historical counts to avoid noisy conclusions.

## Balanced Names (Top Examples)

- Jessie (F: 169,704 | M: 111,202)
- Riley (F: 137,477 | M: 103,344)
- Casey (F: 77,869 | M: 115,589)
- Jackie (F: 91,167 | M: 78,836)
- Johnnie (F: 49,154 | M: 102,028)

## Chart Rationale

I used a grouped bar chart to show female vs male totals side-by-side. It keeps the comparison immediate and avoids confusion when the gap is narrow.

## What I’d Add Next

- Highlight shifts in balance over time (e.g., when a name flips gender dominance)
- Add regional filters to see localized patterns

frontmatter.title: Charting the F5 Breach Impact for Stakeholders
frontmatter.summary: The chart sequence I used to communicate breach impact quickly and clearly.

content:
# Charting the F5 Breach Impact for Stakeholders

This analysis needed to be understood in seconds. I built a small set of charts that move from signal to interpretation without overwhelming the reader.

## 1) Returns Around the Event

A simple line chart of FFIV daily returns around the breach date makes the immediate impact visible.

## 2) DiD Coefficients

I used a coefficient bar chart to show the interaction term alongside the treated and post controls. It keeps focus on the size and direction of the breach effect.

## 3) Robustness Story

The placebo and trend checks are summarized in plain language, with the key numbers highlighted. This keeps the slide deck tight without burying assumptions.

## Outcome

This structure let non-technical stakeholders validate the story quickly and still gave analysts enough detail to trust the results.

frontmatter.title: F5 Breach: Validating DiD Assumptions and Placebo Tests
frontmatter.summary: How I checked parallel trends and ran a placebo test to validate the breach impact analysis.

content:
# F5 Breach: Validating DiD Assumptions and Placebo Tests

Difference-in-Differences only works if the treated and control series behave similarly **before** the event. This post summarizes the quick checks I used to validate the setup.

## Parallel Trends Check

I compared the pre-breach trend of FFIV returns against a basket of peer/benchmark tickers. The lack of a pre-event slope shift supported the DiD setup.

## Placebo Test

I shifted the event date one week earlier and re-estimated the model. The placebo interaction was effectively zero (`treated_post ≈ 0.0042`), which increases confidence that the real event drove the observed effect.

## Takeaway

The strongest evidence still comes from the main DiD interaction (`treated_post ≈ -0.0951`), but the placebo check and trend test make the story defensible.

frontmatter.title: QA Notes on SSA Disability Approval Rates (FY2021)
frontmatter.summary: A short QA checklist for validating state approval rates before publishing.

content:
# QA Notes on SSA Disability Approval Rates (FY2021)

When approval-rate visuals are used in policy contexts, a quick QA pass is essential. Here’s the checklist I used before publishing the FY2021 map and rankings.

## QA Checklist

- Confirm fiscal year filter = FY2021
- Validate state count = 52 (including DC)
- Spot-check top/bottom states for outliers
- Verify rate fields are numeric and within 0–100

## FY2021 Snapshot

- **Highest approval rates:** KS, AK, NH, NE, RI
- **Lowest approval rates:** DC, OK, MS, WV, IN

This QA pass keeps the map trustworthy and avoids misleading readers.

frontmatter.title: Preparing SSA Disability Data for Tableau (FY2001–FY2021)
frontmatter.summary: How I cleaned SSA outcome fields, standardized dates, and exported a Tableau-ready dataset.

content:
# Preparing SSA Disability Data for Tableau (FY2001–FY2021)

The SSA dataset arrives with mixed data types, wide columns, and date formatting inconsistencies. This post summarizes the cleaning steps I used before visualization.

## Cleaning Steps

- Standardized numeric fields (removed commas and cast to numeric)
- Parsed update dates into a consistent format
- Constructed `State-FY` keys for easy map and filter usage

## Output

The result is a Tableau-ready CSV (`ssa_disability_tableau_ready.csv`) with:

- 1,092 rows
- 30 fields
- FY2001–FY2021 coverage

This file drives the choropleth map and ranking charts in the project.
